docs.lead_paragraph: Roaring out of the Democratic convention, in a reprise of their 1992 campaign bus trips, President Clinton, Vice President Al Gore and their wives stormed up and down the mid-Mississippi Valley today, happily bashing Republican proposals -- if not Republicans -- all the way. Like some New Age echo of a Crosby and Hope, the Clintons and the Gores flew here from Chicago this morning to board red, white and blue buses emblazoned with banners proclaiming that they were ''on the road to the 21st century,'' an echo of Mr. Clinton's acceptance speech the night before.

headline.main: Conventions Over, the Candidates Take to the Road

docs.abstract: Pres Clinton and Vice Pres Gore and their wives, in reprise of their 1992 campaign bus trips, storms up and down mid-Mississippi Valley, attacking Republican proposals; trip--trough swing states of Missouri, Illinois, Kentucy and Tennessee--will last two days; in New Mexico, Bob Dole also takes to road; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Roaring out of the Democratic convention, in a reprise of their 1992 campaign bus trips, President Clinton, Vice President Al Gore and their wives stormed up and down the mid-Mississippi Valley today, happily bashing Republican proposals -- if not...

docs.lead_paragraph: Declaring that ''hope is back in America,'' President Clinton accepted his party's nomination for a second term tonight by vowing to protect Government programs for children, the elderly and the environment in a ''strong, united American community.'' In a speech that blended outsized optimism with small-scale proposals, Mr. Clinton summed up his efforts of the last four years and sketched out his plans for the next, claiming credit for a new kind of politics mixing ideas without regard to their partisan origin.

headline.main: CLINTON, DECLARING 'HOPE IS BACK,' DEFENDS HIS FIRST TERM AND LISTS PLANS FOR SECOND

docs.abstract: Pres Clinton accepts Democratic Party nomination for second term, declaring that 'hope is back in America' and vowing to protect children, the elderly and the environment; photos; sums up his efforts over last four years and claims credit for new kind of politics that mixes ideas without regard to their partisan origin; repeats vigorous defense of programs like Medicare and Medicaid while sketching modest new proposals such as tax credits for college education and families, tax breaks for homeowners and job creation; promises to build 'bridge to the 21st century' in contrast to Bob Dole's call for bridge to the past; calls for campaign of ideas, not insults, and says he will not make personal attacks or permit other Democrats to do so if he can help it; Sen Edward Kennedy opens evening with strong assault mocking Republican convention speakers (M)
docs.snippet: Declaring that ''hope is back in America,'' President Clinton accepted his party's nomination for a second term tonight by vowing to protect Government programs for children, the elderly and the environment in a ''strong, united American community.''...

docs.lead_paragraph: Following is President Clinton's speech last night at the Democratic National Convention in which he accepted the party's nomination for re-election as transcribed by The Associated Press: Mr. Chairman, Mr. Vice President, my fellow Democrats, and my fellow Americans. Thank you for your nomination. I don't know if I can find a fancy way to say this, but I accept. Thank you.

headline.main: Clinton's Speech Accepting the Democratic Nomination for President
headline.kicker: THE DEMOCRATS: IN HIS OWN WORDS

docs.lead_paragraph: Following are remarks last night at the Democratic National Convention by Vice President Al Gore: Four years ago, you gave me your nomination to be Vice President. Tonight, I want to say from the bottom of my heart, thank you for the opportunity to serve our country and for the privilege of working beside a President who has done so much to lift the lives of America's families.

headline.main: Gore Speech: 'America Is Strong. Bill Clinton's Leadership Is Paying Off.'

docs.lead_paragraph: The Federal Trade Commission and the Justice Department issued new rules yesterday making it easier for doctors to join together in networks and form other joint ventures to compete with insurance companies and health maintenance organizations. Such collaborations often have been found to violate Federal antitrust laws because the doctors frequently want to agree on prices. The Supreme Court has long held that price-fixing agreements should be automatically condemned as illegal. But the new guidelines will permit many arrangements in which doctors agree on prices if the doctors can show that the agreement promotes competition and benefits consumers.

headline.main: Rules to Ease Forming of Doctor Networks

docs.snippet: The Federal Trade Commission and the Justice Department issued new rules yesterday making it easier for doctors to join together in networks and form other joint ventures to compete with insurance companies and health maintenance organizations.   ...

docs.lead_paragraph: Target Plans to Stop Sales Of Tobacco, Citing Costs The Target chain said it would stop selling cigarettes because it was costing too much to keep them out of the hands of minors. The decision by Target, the nation's third-largest discounter, is the first time such a large retail chain has stopped selling tobacco. But the move is expected to have little impact on the availability of cigarettes. $(Page D4.$) The board of Philip Morris voted to increase the regular quarterly dividend, continuing a 30-year string of increases. $(D4.$) Curbs on tobacco marketing threaten to dry up a source of funds for auto racing. $(B15.$) Block Delays Compuserve Spinoff H & R Block will delay the spinoff of its remaining 80 percent stake in Compuserve, citing the on-line service's recent quarterly losses and uncertainty in the industry. $(D2.$) New Rules for Networks of Doctors The F.T.C. and the Justice Department issued new guidelines making it easier for doctors to band together and form their own networks and other joint ventures to compete with insurance companies and health maintenance organizations. Such collaborations now often run afoul of Federal antitrust law. $(A22.$) Hilton-Ladbroke Deal Expected Hilton Hotels is expected to announce that it has concluded a joint marketing agreement with Ladbroke, the British company that owns the Hilton Hotel chain overseas. $(D4.$) Drug Makers' Earnings Disappoint Ciba-Geigy and Sandoz, which are merging to form a huge drug maker, reported earnings that disappointed analysts. $(D5.$) Blue Chips Edge Up in Light Trading Led by I.B.M., the Dow industrials rose a scant 1.11 points, to 5,712.38, in light trading. The Nasdaq composite rose 4.86 points, to 1,153.88, but the S.& P. 500 was off 1.59, to 664.81. $(D6.$) Traders gave the Government's sale of five-year notes a disappointing reception, halting a one-day improvement in Treasury prices and pushing the yield on the benchmark 30-year bond up to 6.98 percent. $(D16.$) Japan's Economy Remains Weak A Japanese central bank survey of business sentiment signaled that economic recovery had been weaker than expected. $(D5.$) Support for Lloyd's Plan Grows Lloyd's of London said more of its investors had agreed to its rescue plan. $(D5.$) Deal for Little, Brown Unit The Dutch publishing house Wolters Kluwer plans to buy a Little, Brown unit. $(D3.$) Ambitious Egg Farmer Or Capitalist Villain? For decades, Jack DeCoster was an emblem of hard work and ambition in Turner, Me., a self-made multi-millionaire who started out with 125 hens, and created an agricultural empire: Five million hens producing 23 million brown and white eggs a week. But questions about working conditions have turned Turner's hometown-boy-made-good into one of capitalism's villains. $(A18.$) Medical Journal Drug Controversy The New England Journal of Medicine ran an editorial favorable to a new weight-loss drug that was written by authors paid by the drug's maker, Interneuron Pharmaceutical. The Journal's editor said she suspected ''a misunderstanding.'' $(D18.$)

docs.lead_paragraph: THE exasperating thing about having a law practice that specializes in serving older people, Lawrence E. Davidow says, is all the calls from other lawyers seeking advice. ''We call them the yodelers,'' Mr. Davidow said. ''They always start out the same way: 'I've got this little old lady who . . .' ''

headline.main: Longer Lives Create a Field Of Legal Need

docs.abstract: Elder law becomes a booming legal specialty because of the aging of American population; one part of practice, known as Medicaid estate planning, is targeted in the health-insurance bill just signed by Pres Clinton, which makes it a criminal offense to dispose of assets in order to obtain Medicaid benefits, primarily for nursing-home care; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Federal Trade Commission and the Justice Department issued new guidelines today making it easier for doctors to band together and form their own networks and other joint ventures to compete with insurance companies and health maintenance organizations. Such collaborations now often run afoul of Federal antitrust law because doctors in the same network frequently want to agree on prices. For decades, the Supreme Court has held that price-fixing agreements in general are so harmful to competition that they should be automatically condemned as illegal, regardless of their purpose.

headline.main: U.S. Issues Guidelines to Help Doctors Form Health Networks

docs.abstract: Federal Trade Commission and Justice Department issue new guidelines making it easier for doctors to band together and form their own networks and other joint ventures to compete with insurance companies and health maintenance organizations; new guidelines will give approval to many arrangements in which doctors agree on prices if they can show agreement benefits consumers (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: For more than three decades, Jack DeCoster has been an emblem of hard work and ambition in this little farming town, a self-made multimillionaire who started out with 125 hens and created an agricultural empire: Five million hens producing 23 million brown and white eggs a week. ''Jack doesn't fish, he doesn't hunt, he doesn't go to nightclubs,'' said Ralph Caldwell, a local dairy farmer. ''He does business -- 18 hours a day.''

headline.main: In Maine, Egg Empire Is Under Fire

docs.abstract: DeCoster Egg Farm in Turner, Me, family-owned business once considered emblem of hard work and ambition, has been fined $3.6 million for safety and health violations; owner Jack DeCoster, community's hometown-boy-made-good, has been transformed into capitalist villain by expose in local newspaper; Labor Sec Robert Reich labeled company agricultural sweatshop where workers were treated like animals; photo; map (M)
docs.snippet: For more than three decades, Jack DeCoster has been an emblem of hard work and ambition in this little farming town, a self-made multimillionaire who started out with 125 hens and created an agricultural empire: Five million hens producing 23 million...

docs.lead_paragraph: On Thursday night, when he accepts the renomination of a Democratic Party that he has alternately inspired and exasperated, William Jefferson Clinton will be at once the best-known and least-knowable politician in the land. He is a moderate who cannot suppress his liberal impulses, a liberal who cannot escape his moderating instincts. He confounds his friends, who think he has agreed with them, only to find he has not. He confuses his enemies, who think they can work with him, only to find they cannot.

headline.main: The Incumbent as a Riddle: William Jefferson Clinton
headline.kicker: THE DEMOCRATS: MAN IN THE NEWS
